page.title: 15VEGETATION AROUND GRANTOWN
page.content:
In past centuries the area was covered by woodland. Parts of this{CALEDONIAN {FOREST}can still be seen in the area, mainly isolated Scots Pine. Through time most of the forest was replaced by heather moorland, which now covers much of the upland area. This is good feeding for grouse and is "fired" from time to time to encourage young, tender shoots.
Broadleaved woodland, mainly Beech and Oak, is found on the valley floor. It was planted along the river banks and in the parkland around Castle Grant and Home Farm. Many of the trees are almost two hundred years old. More recently plantations of softwood have been set up, run by the Forestry Commission or Seafield Estates. Many of these plantations are now ready for felling.
